Caption: For decades the ocean has absorbed the impact of burning fossil fuels. But now with record-breaking marine heatwaves ecosystems are reaching their limits   and we re all #InHotWater.  From coral bleaching to more powerful storms the impacts are cascading across our blue planet. Coastal communities marine life and our future is at risk.It s time to stop burning fossil fuels and urgently transition to renewables.The ocean   and all of us   depend on it. #COP29 #ActForOurPlanet

The Arctic is warming almost THREE TIMES faster than the rest of the planet. A warmer Arctic accelerates global heating rise in sea levels loss of ecosystems and more. To safeguard the Arctic and our planet the amount of greenhouse gas emissions being released into the atmosphere must decrease.Double tap if you want leaders to take greater climate action! #COP29

2024 was just declared the hottest year on record. We need bold action in 2025   more renewable energy ecosystem restoration and ambitious climate goals. Our window to avoid the worst impacts is closing fast and those who ve contributed the least emissions are suffering the most. The time for talk is over. We must act now to protect our planet and the communities in the most vulnerable situations.
POV: It s Monday morning but you re still in weekend mode...

Tiny-but-mighty: Monarch butterflies make one of the largest insect migrations in the world!Their journey spans an incredible 2500 miles  Throughout their migration they play a crucial role in pollination.However climate change deforestation and land conversion have hit them hard. In just 20 years we ve seen an alarming 80% population decline.We must band together to protect this essential and amazing species. Double tap if you agree

The future of our planet is shaped by incredible individuals and communities. Because they are #NaturesHeroes.Like wwfmy Tiger Anti-Poaching Team and Sarawak Wildlife Conservation Team.Through their incredible work they have:  Achieved a 98% reduction in active snares and capturing footage of Malayan tiger cubs  Collected over a million images through camera traps and conducting orangutan nest surveys in Sarawak  Bettered survival for our endangered speciesTheir hard work has earned each team a Star Golden Hearts Award 2024   recognising their extraordinary commitment to Malaysia s wildlife.Here s to a year filled with hope resilience and continued progress in conservation. Share if you are with us!

#BREAKING: The #IberianLynx population has grown 21% in one year reaching 2021 last year.  This remarkable growth brings the species halfway to its full recovery.This historic milestone was made possible by 21 organisations including WWFspain. Double tap to show your support  ...#wildlife #nature #environment #conservation

The local communities of the Ile-Balkhash region are helping drive the historic return of tigers to Kazakhstan after 70 years of extinction.  Last year an ambitious project saw two Amur tigers Bodhana and Kuma making a roaring comeback to the area. From adopting sustainable farming practices to preparing for eco-tourism the communities are helping the Ile-Balkhash delta. They are restoring critical species   like the Bukhara deer and Kulan   and replanting forests. Their efforts are not just bringing back tigers   they re bringing life pride and prosperity to the region.This ambitious project   by wereldnatuurfonds the Kazakh government and UNDP   shows #NaturesHeroes are key to conservation successes.
POV: It s Monday morning but you re still in weekend mode...

Stop scrolling and take a moment to witness something truly special In celebration of #WorldWildlifeDay we re excited to share never-before-seen camera trap footage of leopards and tigers in northeast China. These incredible animals are thriving thanks to years of conservation efforts focused on habitat restoration.But there s still more work to be done because when we protect tigers we protect so much more  #WorldWildlifeDay

Plastics are everywhere   in the air we breathe the food we eat and the water we drink. Governments will soon gather for the final round of negotiations on a Global Plastic Pollution Treaty. Decisions made in these negotiations will determine the future for today s children and generations to come. Failure to agree on a strong binding treaty risks turning a moment of hope into one of irreversible harm. The world is watching. In the heart of Laos the Nam Poui National Protected Area is a haven for rare wildlife including the iconic Asian #elephant.But despite its beauty this vast forest faces hidden threats like illegal logging and rampant snaring.Through data collection and community engagement WWF-Laos and local communities are working tirelessly to safeguard these majestic creatures and restore their home.Double tap to show your support for elephants

Marine heatwaves are breaking records as the #ClimateCrisis accelerates and sea temperatures are hitting all-time highs. Hotter water holds less oxygen making it hard for some fish to survive. Fish like tuna can migrate to cooler waters but this unexpected movement disrupts coastal communities and global seafood supply chains.  Marine heatwaves are just one way we face the consequences of a warming planet. But there s hope. By reducing fossil fuels and protecting resilient ecosystems we can #SaveOurOcean. Share this if you re with us!  ....coralreefrescueinitiative #WWFUntangled
Live footage of us this holiday season. Best wishes to you all! comedywildlifephoto

The Sumatra forest is not just beautiful it s a lifeline for us all:  The forest s trees are Earth s natural air purifiers. They absorb carbon dioxide and give us the fresh clean air we need to breathe.  It helps to regulate global climate patterns.  It s woven into the cultural fabric of the region. It s not just trees it s stories traditions and a connection to the land that sustains us.  It s a treasure trove of unique species. Preserving it ensures the delicate balance of our ecosystems supporting countless plant and animal species.  It s crucial for maintaining water cycles ensuring a steady and clean water supplyLet s stand together to protect the Sumatra forest   because when we care for nature we re safeguarding our well-being. Double tap if you agree!

You can find it on the highest peaks and in the deepest seas. In your home. In your food. And yes even in your body  Plastic. It s everywhere   and it s getting out of hand. If we keep going at this rate plastic pollution could triple by 2040.  The global plastic treaty is our one chance to #StopPlasticPollution. Tap the link in our bio to demand for change. #INC4 #EarthDay
Did you know? There are over 60000 known species of trees in the world.  And more are being identified to science every year!

Severe drought is dangerous for people and nature. And they re made worse by the changes in our climate   lasting longer and longer.This is the story of what happened in Kenya during such a time. In 2022 a drought in the country threatened the lives of people their livestock and wildlife to an unprecedented degree. In fact it threatened to wipe out a generation of elephants.This crisis demands urgent climate action. Share to help spread the word  WWF_Kenya

THIS is shocking: In just under 20 years global plastic waste has doubled   Driven by single-use plastic products.And the people most impacted? They re the people who have done the least to contribute to the plastics crisis.We can t let this pattern continue   It s time for governments to champion a robust #GlobalPlasticsTreaty that safeguards people and the planet. We must turn single-use to #ZeroUse. Help us #StopPlasticPollution. Tap the link in our bio to take action!

Meet some of the #NewMekongSpecies newly recorded by science each a unique wonder of nature yet already under threat.From habitat destruction to illegal wildlife trade these dangers mean countless species might vanish before we even know they exist.  Double tap if you agree we must do more to protect our planet s amazing nature.

Did you know? When green turtles munch on seagrass they make it grow better and more nutritious. Their grazing helps the seagrass thrive which traps sediments and protects our coastlines from erosion storms and rising sea levels.Every year thousands of sea turtles face numerous threats. But thanks to the efforts of WWF Malaysia and local communities these magnificent animals have a fighting chance. From protecting nesting sites to rescuing injured turtles every action counts. Double tap to show your support for these amazing animals and our oceans!   wwfmy
Did you know? #CoralReefs cover only 0.1% of the area of the ocean but they support a quarter of all marine species on the planet.What s your favourite fact about our planet?

Jaguars in Latin America are in danger.They ve lost 50% of their original range and threats like hunting and environmental changes aren t slowing down. As apex predators jaguars are vital for keeping ecosystems in balance and supporting the healthy environments people depend on.It s time to rebrand their future   not just for jaguars but for the planet we all call home. Share this post: Let s make a change.   #ConnectingTheSpots #InternationalJaguarDay

#BREAKING! This is code red for nature: Species population numbers have plummeted by 73% on average since 1970.This is getting worse over time when it should be getting better. Vital ecosystems are on the brink of collapse. We re dangerously close to tipping points where the damage to our planet will cause irreversible impacts on all our lives.The signs are clear: we must act NOW. Not tomorrow not next year. Urgent action is needed immediately.It s time to act like our lives depend on it. Because they do.  Share this video to #ActForOurPlanet...#LPR2024 #LivingPlanetReport

The Himalayas   one of the worlds most iconic mountain ranges   are a crucial source of freshwater for millions of people downstream. They remind us that mountains play a vital role in maintaining our planets delicate ecosystems. Lets work together to protect these majestic giants and ensure a sustainable future for all!   jamesmorganfoto

Citizen scientists help make amazing discoveries!  Thanks to their efforts new species are being recorded. The discovery of Begonia kayinensis wouldn t have been possible without the involvement of citizen scientists  says Mya Bhone Maw a PhD student documenting Myanmar s biodiversity in remote under-researched areas.  .#CitizenScience

A stunning pit viper with scales that look like long eyelashes   A leafless orchid found in a market  A ginger species with a root that smells like mangoThese are just some of the species in the Mekong which have not been previously recorded by science!But many of these species are already under threat of extinction.Double tap if you agree governments must better protect these rare amazing animals and their habitats.

Today four billion people experience severe water scarcity for at least one month every year. And half of the world s corals have already been lost.This is because nature is in crisis.  Right now it s being destroyed at a rate unprecedented in human history.We must act now to protect people and nature   and work together to overcome one of the greatest challenges of our time. We need to reverse nature loss ending the decade with more nature than we started with not less.  Leaders: The time to act is NOW. Share this post to call for action!...#WWFUntangled #BiodiversityDay #nature #climatecrisis

What does chilli have to do with elephants?  For Mathews Chilambe and Chamunolwa Jimayi the answer is a creative solution to reduce human-elephant conflict in South Dambwa Zambia.As members of the Conservation and Tourism Society (CATS) Mathews and Chamunolwa have turned chili into a powerful tool for both conservation and community support.Through an innovative outgrower scheme CATS purchases locally grown chilli providing farmers with a steady income and a reliable market. The chili is then transformed into chilli bricks    natural deterrents that help keep elephants away from crops and villages.Their approach is all about bringing people and wildlife together ensuring a peaceful coexistence. #NaturesHeroes like Mathews and Chamunolwa are leading the way toward a future where people live in harmony with nature. wereldnatuurfonds

Take two breaths  did you do it?  Now thank the ocean because it produces half the oxygen you breathe   all day every day!  It also absorbs heat and CO2 from the atmosphere. Really it s working round the clock to keep our climate in balance. But our ocean is in trouble. Since the 1970s populations of oceanic sharks and rays have plummeted by over 70%. It s vital we reduce the pressure from overfishing and climate change protect habitats and reduce plastic pollution  Share this post to give our ocean a voice!

Migratory freshwater fishes are in freefall with populations crashing by 81% on average in the past 50 years due to hydropower dams habitat loss overexploitation and pollution. And increasing climate change.Why is this important? Migratory fishes are critical to the food security of 100+ million people the cultures of Indigenous Peoples & local communities and recreational fishing industries worth billions.They re also essential to the health of our rivers and countless other species.Double tap if you agree we must better protect nature and people!

#DYK without mangroves 15M more people would be affected by floods each year?   Mangroves connect rivers oceans and coasts protecting us from storms and erosion. Safeguarding them helps our entire ecosystem. Show love for these natural superheroes!   #WorldOceansDay
Fossil fuels fuel #ClimateChange. It s time to change that.  Not tomorrow not in a year   actions must start now!World leaders must urgently #ActForOurPlanet. #COP29

Our food starts with the soil beneath our feet. From the veggies on your plate to the grains in your bread healthy soil is where it all begins. And it s the tiniest soil engineers like dung beetles that help keep it that way. Without them our food system and ecosystems could be at risk.  Protecting life below ground is crucial for food security planetary health and human well-being.As leaders meet at the Biodiversity conference   #COP16Colombia   we call on them to #ActForOurPlanet #NaturesTechnicians

Asian elephants in Southeast Asia and China face many issues due to human actions and their overall populations are dramatically decreasing. Decision-makers need to take greater action to protect nature and people. Double tap if you agree

Turn up the sound and listen closely: the urgency is real.Countries from around the world are coming together to break records get victory and show what s possible with hard work and commitment.But these incredible teams and athletes aren t the only ones breaking records. There are other records being broken too   records we can t celebrate.  From extreme weather events to unprecedented wildfires climate records are being shattered everywhere on our planet. Incredible human effort and determination bring success in the arena. It shows that anything s possible when people put in the work. Double tap if you want greater action to protect our shared home!
Asian elephants in Southeast Asia and China face many issues due to human actions and their overall populations are dramatically decreasing. Share this to help spread the word!

The ocean provides us with so much   from the food we eat to the air we breathe! It s also a vital ally in stopping the #ClimateCrisis.Now more than ever we must protect our blue planet. Share this post to help turn the tide!

To the leaders at #COP16Colombia: the world is watching!  At #COP15 in December 2022 196 countries committed to halt and reverse nature loss by 2030 through the Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF). But progress has been too slow and the challenge is bigger than ever.  We need to act much faster and at a much larger scale. With just six years left to meet global targets its time for leaders and decision makers to go from agreement to action.Share this post to call on them to #ActForOurPlanet

Wildlife is the hidden force that keeps our world running   but its at high risk. Average species population numbers have plummeted by 73% since 1970 putting ecosystems economies and livelihoods at risk.Yet global leaders still aren t prioritising biodiversity loss.Promises won t cut it. We need critical financial resources to halt and reverse wildlife decline.From vultures preventing disease  by disposing of carcasses efficiently to monkeys restoring forests through seed dispersal wildlife isn t just beautiful   it s essential. At #COP16 leaders must move from words to action. Our futures depend on it.  The time for action is now. For people and nature. #COP16 #WWFUntangled #NaturesTechnicians

It s France s most iconic river. But for decades the Seine was treated like a sewer. It was so polluted that it was functionally  dead . But now it is coming back to life thanks to a huge clean-up effort.From 3 fish species to over 30.   And waters that are almost swimmable.With the world gathering for the #ParisOlympics the Seine s restoration is a striking testament to nature s powers of recovery.Our partner Minaguli is running the entire river to showcase the Seine and call on other cities and countries to restore their rivers   for people and nature. #RunBlue #GenerationRestoration

Behold the first-ever photograph of the elusive New Britain Goshawk photographed during a recent WWF scoping trip to Pomio! This remarkable bird is only found on the island of New Britain in Papua New Guinea and is rarely seen.But this is just the beginning. Together with local communities and leaders WWFPacific wwfbelgium are taking bold steps to protect Papua New Guinea s incredible biodiversity through community-led conservation.  Share this to show your love for our planet s amazing nature   by tomvierus...#GoodNewsFriday
These are the records we don t want to break.Double tap if you want to see greater action to #ChangeClimateChange!

The deep sea is a realm of wonder and mystery.  But climate change overfishing and plastic pollution wreak havoc on our ocean. And now this mesmerising underwater world is facing another threat: #DeepSeaMining.Together we can stop this threat before it s too late. Double tap if you agree governments must stop the irreversible damage of the deep sea now! #ThinkDeeply

#DYK Without mangroves 15 MILLION more people would be affected by floods each year.   This is major!Restoring and protecting nature is one of the best ways we can help safeguard this one home we all share. Heres why #mangroves are an amazing example of that.

Mangroves are amazing climate heroes!  They re home to a dazzling array of wildlife defend coastlines from storms and help keep our climate in balance.They re some of the world s most valuable ecosystems   but also the most threatened.Climate change unsustainable coastal development and pollution are just a few reasons mangroves are disappearing.Double tap if you agree we must do more to protect our precious mangrove forests.
True or false? There are more living organisms in a single teaspoon of soil than there are people on Earth.  Soil is a bustling ecosystem that s essential for a healthy planet.

Indigenous Peoples   from the Colombian #Amazon to the Arctic   are vital to safeguarding nature but often excluded from decisions about their future.Its vital their rights are upheld knowledge respected and that they are supported to govern their territories of life.Their active involvement is key to achieving our global biodiversity goals and building a sustainable future for all.   #COP16Colombia #ActForOurPlanet

No matter where you are in the world what happens to the Amazon rainforest will impact you.  And decades of deforestation and climate-driven degradation threaten this essential ecosystem. If it continues the vibrant Amazon could turn into dry forests and grassland   devastating nature people and the planet.This can only change if we #ActForOurPlanet now. To protect the Amazon and its irreplaceable value. #WWFUntangled #LivingPlanetReport #LPR2024

What happens when you mix bees and elephants?   In Zimbabwe beehives serve as natural barriers keeping elephants away from crops and protecting harvests. This ingenious solution not only conserves wildlife but also provides alternative income during droughts supporting local communities.   Double tap if you support these creative conservation efforts!

Nature continues to amaze us!The elusive Lesula monkey the dwarf water cobra and the slender-snouted crocodile are some of the 742 species in the Congo Basin which have not been previously recorded by science  Double tap to show your love for our planets incredible biodiversity

Mountain gorillas are vital to our planet s health   but the climate crisis is pushing them to the brink  Climate change is increasingly exposing them to wild fires and reducing their food and water sources while habitat loss and disease threats also endanger their survival.As ecosystem guardians they help forests thrive support biodiversity and sustain local communities through eco-tourism. Their decline threatens not just wildlife but livelihoods and cultural heritage too.  Their conservation is crucial. Swipe to learn more & share to spread awareness #TheHerds

Did you know that 80% of the people displaced by climate change are women?Women and girls especially Indigenous women and women of colour are among the most vulnerable to the impacts of the #ClimateCrisis. But theyre also key agents for change. Women s contribution to nature-based solutions and climate adaptation creates a ripple effect for families and communities.Empowering women is crucial for a world where people and nature thrive. Its vital their voices be heard. They must be equally represented to drive change. ....#COP29 #ActForOurPlanet

This is the dramatic shrinking of the Aral Sea in just a few decades.  Excessive water extraction along with other factors has pushed this once-thriving body of water to the brink. This isn t just an environmental crisis it s a human one too. Losing the Aral Sea has devastated local communities affecting livelihoods health and food security. This drastic change shows how our actions in one part of the world can impact everyone.We re taking too much from our planet and not giving enough back. It s time to change our ways and protect our shared home.

Big or small wild animals are vital to the health of our planet   and to our own survival. Like parrotfish.   In marine reserves where parrot fishing is prohibited coral reefs are SIX TIMES more resilient to bleaching and other disturbances. The #NaturesTechnicians report shows just how essential biodiversity   from mammals to invertebrates   is in maintaining the resilience of ecosystems.As #COP16Colombia approaches it s crucial that leaders #ActForOurPlanet. Our future depends on it. #WWFUntangledDiscover more in our story.

What does it take to restore habitats for wild elephants? Kui Buri National Park Thailand once pineapple fields is being transformed into a haven for wild elephants. WWF-Thailand (wwfthailand) and local communities are creating waterholes planting grasses and replenishing food sources to support the growing elephant population and other wildlife. Their efforts are once again helping these majestic creatures thrive in their natural habitat. Double tap to show your love for #elephants!

It s true.  If we lose rivers lakes and wetlands we lose the water that sustains us our food and other species.Because water doesn t just come from the tap it comes from nature.   Without urgent action over half of the world s population could face severe water shortages by 2030.Healthy freshwater environments underpin societies and economies. We need to restore and protect our freshwater. Share this post if you re with us!

Local action = global impact   And Natalia Botero-Acosta is the perfect example. As the Director of macuaticos Natalia is making a huge impact in her community and beyond. With her work focused on the Gulf of Tribug  on Colombia s Pacific coast Natalia is collaborating closely with the local community to study and protect humpback whales. Over the years her conservation efforts have deeply engaged the community. A touching example: Neymar first got involved in the project as a boat assistant is now an active field team member helping launch drones to study whales from the sky.For the future of people and the planet #NaturesHeroes like Natalia are leading the change!

Changing our ways can change our planet!   Zinori Bikorwomuhangi a former illegal forest harvester now collaborates with his community to turn poachers into conservationists. Together they re planting more trees than they ever cut protecting wildlife and fostering sustainable livelihoods. Share this post to spread the word: We can all make a difference for people and the planet

River dolphins are extraordinary. They are the apex predators in some of the world s greatest river systems.  But were losing them. River dolphin populations have plummeted by 73% since the 1980s.Double tap if you want greater protection for nature and people!

The island of Runde in Norway is home to more than 200 bird species - including Gannets Shags Puffins Razorbills Oystercatchers and many more. But their home is being overrun with plastic ghost gear - discarded at sea and collected by the birds to build their nests to raise their young. This is not the way it is supposed to be. But even though they can t always be seen their presence in their environment helps maintain the delicate balance of nature. We can t let them disappear. For people and the planet.And citizen scientists help us understand more about these animals.

Why does protecting tigers matter to us all? Landscapes with wild tigers are healthy and vibrant ecosystems which are critically important in a climate-changing world. Double tap to show your   for tigers!...#tigerfinance #investintigers #tigers

On the island of Chilo    along Chile s southern coast   women are working to advance their rights and sustainable fishing.For generations women s roles in fishing communities have been overlooked. But leaders like Carola Barr a are changing the story. She s pushing for gender equity organising training for female leaders and ensuring women have a voice in fisheries management.Other female leaders are taking action too as a coalition. They are empowering their community championing equity in the male-dominated fishing industry and protecting ancestral fishing grounds all while mentoring the next generation and preserving traditions.This movement   supported by WWFChile   shows #NaturesHeroes are the key to sustainable development and conservation.

Unlike migratory species corals stay put making them uniquely vulnerable to marine heatwaves. More heat or one big storm could wipe them out. The impacts are global. When we lose corals many coastal communities lose an important source of food and livelihoods.Let s cut fossil fuels and protect ecosystems to #SaveOurOcean. Double tap if you re with us!   coralreefrescueinitiative

We need URGENT action to address the #ClimateCrisis.But what can we do?  Safeguarding nature is a crucial step towards safeguarding our shared home  Double tap if you want more climate action! #COP29 #ActForOurPlanet

The Motagua River   once a lifeline for people and wildlife in Guatemala and Honduras   is now drowning in plastic pollution.  We need a strong binding global treaty to stop harmful plastic products and chemicals.  Visit the link in our bio to vote YES for a strong global plastic pollution treaty. Let s save our rivers and protect our planet.   ..#BanIt #SaveOurRivers #StopPlasticPollution #UNGA

By combining their local culture and ancestral knowledge with formal protection local communities in Kavewa Fiji are working together to build climate and community resilience to protect their Cakaulevu.  Cakaulevu also known as Fiji s Great Sea Reef is the third-longest continuous barrier reef system in the world.  Its health is directly linked to the #IndigenousPeoples across Fiji who rely on its resources for their livelihood well-being and culture. It also contributes to global climate resilience and food supply chains across the world.  Their inspiring efforts to protect this irreplaceable seascape are already reaping benefits. Double tap to show your support!

Temperatures in the Arctic have risen almost three times faster than the global average. This is disrupting ocean ecosystems and the livelihoods of many people.Leaders: Now is the time for committed action for people and nature. Share this post to raise awareness! ..#UNGA

Trees provide us with oxygen shelter food and so much more. Their diversity is not only fascinating but also critical for maintaining a healthy planet. Double tap to celebrate the many wonders of trees

We need URGENT action in the midst of global climate disasters.But what can we do? Safeguarding nature helps us combat the #ClimateCrisis  Double tap if you agree our planet needs greater climate action!

Amazon pink river dolphins are some of the oldest animals on Earth.  But   in just 22 years   their population numbers have dropped by 65%. Last year extreme heat and drought resulted in the deaths of over 330 Amazon pink river dolphins and tucuxis in two lakes in the State of Amazonas. This is the current  state of our planet   and we can t let it continue.We need action to put an end to biodiversity loss. It s time leaders #ActForOurPlanet people and nature. Double tap if you agree! ..#COP16Colombia

Tipping points are alarming. But there is a silver lining.  The world has recognised the need for change. And this awareness is a great starting point. Now we need action.Share this to help raise awareness!...#ActForOurPlanet #WWFUntangled #LivingPlanetReport #LPR2024

More time in nature = more happiness!  Research shows people who spend at least 2 hours a week in nature have a greater sense of well-being than those who dont.Tell us   how do you like to spend your time in nature?

We are on course to lose up to 90% of coral reefs by 2050. The record-breaking heat stress damaging coral across most of the #GreatBarrierReef is now officially part of a global mass bleaching event accelerating this loss. Protecting sacred Sea Country is up to all of us.

Thats a wrap!  Mina has run the entire 800km length of this beautiful river in just 30 days. Her WWF-backed #SeineRiverRun proves how we can do hard things when we commit. Not long ago the Seine was declared functionally dead. Today it s being restored to health through dedicated clean-up efforts.  Protecting and restoring rivers worldwide is crucial for biodiversity clean water climate resilience community benefits and a sustainable future.  Every effort counts. Together we can make a difference.  #WWF #RiverRestoration #SaveOurRivers #Biodiversity #ClimateAction #CleanWater #Community #SustainableFuture #RunBlue

Meet May Samorn a dedicated Ranger for the Royal Government of Cambodia  He works closely with our research team to protect Cambodias incredible wildlife and plays a crucial role in numerous conservation efforts such as camera trap surveys elephant research and much more.  Double tap to show your support for the unsung heroes of our planet!

Just like a see-saw nature has a tipping point. If we continue its unprecedented destruction we risk pushing ecosystems past the point of no return. And the impact? It will affect everyone everywhere. We ve may have placed our planet on a dangerous see-saw but if we #ActForOurPlanet   NOW   we can still tip things back in our favour.Playtime is over. It s time to get to work. #WWFUntangled #LivingPlanetReport #LPR2024

Forests are our lifelines providing oxygen water and livelihoods.   In Zambia community-led conservation is helping safeguard forests. Local heroes conduct prescribed burns to protect these precious resources from wildfires and illegal logging.   Together they ensure our forests remain standing and thriving.  Lets support these efforts to ensure these lifelines remain standing.

A team led by #Indigenous women from four communities in Western Province Solomon Islands   is using their expertise to implement nature-based solutions for their benefit while protecting threatened ecosystems proving that it is possible to:Preserve culture  Conserve nature  Earn income to support your family  Today 40-90% of their weekly income comes directly from selling sea grapes.  And they re only getting started! Double tap to show your support  ...#IndigenousPeoplesDay #NbS #NaturebasedSolutions

To help them and address this worsening crisis decision-makers must secure a strong treaty to #StopPlasticPollution....#BanIt #StopPlasticPollution #INC5

Coral reefs are amazing.   They support the livelihoods of 850 million people globally and are essential to 25% of all marine life   despite covering less than 1% of the ocean floor.But as temperatures rise our oceans are feeling the heat. Marine heatwaves are threatening coral reefs coastal communities and our future.Without urgent action we could lose these vibrant and important ecosystems forever threatening the well-being of people and nature.But there are solutions. By cutting fossil fuels and protecting resilient reefs we can #SaveOurOceans   if we act now. Share this post if you re with us! .coralreefrescueinitiative #WWFUntangled #WorldCoralReefDay #WorldReefDay

Nature unites us.  Forests provide us with food clean water and protection against natural hazards like floods.  One community in Oaxaca Mexico is uniting to restore and sustainably manage their forest and watershed - for the benefit of communities all the way along their river. Restoring the forest restores the river flow. We depend on water from this region. If our river collapses we will all collapse. The community s relationship with nature is shaped by Zapotec culture and traditions which empowers them to create sustainable livelihoods. We are different but we are united. Water unites us.  #RestorationWorks
How are you helping to #StopPlasticPollution?Tell us in the comments   #INC4

Flying Furballs: Bettongs Take to the Skies!Seventy-three brush-tailed bettongs are on a mission impossible - but with a touch of marsupial magic!  Flown over 2000 kilometres from Western Australia to Dhilba Guuranda-Innes National Park in South Australia these tiny marsupials are the heart of an ambitious project - Marna Banggara.  Supported by dedicated teams from WWF Australia Zoos SA DEW and more this effort aims to restore locally extinct species to South Australia s Yorke Peninsula as part of the Marna Banggara project.Thanks to our partners including the Northern and Yorke Landscape Board and the Australian Government were rewriting the story of endangered species conservation!

Rivers are our lifelines providing us with food water livelihoods connection and more. We need to treat them like our lives depend on them   because they do.That s why Minaguli is setting off on an extraordinary campaign today: to run the length of France s Seine River ahead of the #ParisOlympics.That s the equivalent of 20 marathons in a month from Source to Sea. And she s not doing it because she loves running. Or because she s an Olympic-level athlete.She s doing it to celebrate the work to bring the Seine back to life.And with the world gathering in Paris to highlight the need for all cities and countries to restore their rivers. For people and nature we must protect them. Double tap if you re with us!#SeineRiverRun #RunBlue #GenerationRestoration #WorldEnvironmentDay #GlobalRunningDay
